pages.name: Notice of Lawyer for Child
pages.description:
Rule 161 says that if a case involves a child, the child’s views must be considered unless it is inappropriate to do so.

One way to have the child’s views heard by the court is for a child to have their own lawyer to represent their interests. Other ways include a views of the child report or the judge interviewing the child directly.

Permission of the court is not required for a lawyer to begin representing the interests of a child but a court order may be needed if a lawyer needs to be appointed by the court.

It is up to the court to determine how a child’s evidence will be heard, as appropriate.

elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice1
elements.title: How does a lawyer for a child get appointed?
elements.body:
Where it is in the best interests of a child to be represented in a family law case, any party to the case can apply under s. 203 of the Family Law Act for a lawyer to represent the interests of the child. An application can be made using the Application for Case Management Order in Form 10. You can apply for a case management order using this service.

If the court agrees that it is in the child’s best interests, the court may appoint a lawyer for that child. The order might also include how the lawyer’s fees will be paid and by whom.

Children or parents can contact the Society for Children and Youth of British Columbia’s Child and Youth Legal Centre for more information about getting a lawyer for a child. The Centre provides legal support for young people.

elements.name: pageIntro
elements.html:
Are you a lawyer representing a child in a family law case?

Rule 162 of the Provincial Court Family Rules requires you to file a Notice of Lawyer for Child in Form 40 when you start representing a child and serve a copy on each other party as soon as possible.

The Notice of Lawyer for Child can be used at any time in a court proceeding.

Use this pathway to complete your Notice of Lawyer for Child.
